messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid question
messages.msgSnippet: Hi All, How do you Repatinate?  What is the solution or recipe for the solution? Kim
messages.messageBody:
Hi All,
How do you Repatinate? What is the solution or recipe for the solution?

Kim

Ron Hartmann wrote:

>Rich -
>
>Repatination of tsuba can be done--correctly--but refinishing such as removing pits, etc., no, I don't think anyone would want to do that. Sometimes a terrific tsuba is found that has been buffed or whatever and then, repatination can be done to save it. Skip Holbrook used to do this but today--if I understand things correctly--only handles really high quality tsuba. We all experiement with repatination I'm sure, but care must be taken not to (further) damage an important quality tsuba.
>
>Several years ago a Japanese gentleman (artist) was at one of the sword shows displaying his prize-winning newly made tsuba. His tsuba were traditionally made and quite beatufiul...and quite expensive! So there are those around today who continue the craft.
>
>Ron
>STL

> From: Richard Turner
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Thursday, May 12, 2005 4:57 AM
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid question
>
>
> LOL, sorry mate, I wasn't asking if I COULD DO IT, but rather, are there
> any professionals in Japan doing this sort of thing.
>
> We would not expect you to be able to restore tsuba LOL.
>
> Rich
>
> Barry Thomas wrote:
>
> > I'm no expert by any means ("X" = an unknown factor and "spurt" is a
> > drip under pressure!!!), but when Trickie writes:
> >
> > > My question for the day then is, if we polish and restore pittings,
> > > scratches, chips and the likes from swords, is anything like this
> > > ever done on iron tsuba ?
> >
> > my answer would be
> >
> > NOooooooo...
> >
> > How do I know?? In my early days I stuffed a reasonable tsuba or two
> > trying to "restore" them (boo, hisss, shame, brickbats...). So, I
> > wouldn't advise this at all. Over to an expert???
> >
> > Regards,

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid question
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 5/12/2005 1:54:19 A.M. Central Daylight Time, ikkanshi@westnet.com.au writes: wondered  about the recipes in the back of the Aesthetic Guide
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 5/12/2005 1:54:19 A.M. Central Daylight Time,
ikkanshi@... writes:

wondered about the recipes in the
back of the Aesthetic Guide and if anyone still does this stuff. If so,
could very good tsuba with minimal damage be repaired and re patinate
and if so, how effectively.



I suspect most tsuba collectors do a little " restorations ". Getting rid
of active rust with a little horn/ivory rub job for example, wearing it in
your pocket is another.
I restored ( more than rust removal) a tsuba that passed Hagihara sensei's
scrutiny and passed shinsa always brings a little grin to my face.
Have discussed the " ways " with a few tsuba scholars/collectors, seems like
there are a few methods out there . I wouldn't recommend trying them on
good tsuba at the get go, but you can try your hands at the typical po-edo
39.99 rusty thingie and learn about iron...................

milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid question
messages.msgSnippet: Rich - Repatination of tsuba can be done--correctly--but refinishing such as removing pits, etc., no, I don t think anyone would want to do that. Sometimes a
messages.messageBody:
Rich -

Repatination of tsuba can be done--correctly--but refinishing such as removing pits, etc., no, I don't think anyone would want to do that. Sometimes a terrific tsuba is found that has been buffed or whatever and then, repatination can be done to save it. Skip Holbrook used to do this but today--if I understand things correctly--only handles really high quality tsuba. We all experiement with repatination I'm sure, but care must be taken not to (further) damage an important quality tsuba.

Several years ago a Japanese gentleman (artist) was at one of the sword shows displaying his prize-winning newly made tsuba. His tsuba were traditionally made and quite beatufiul...and quite expensive! So there are those around today who continue the craft.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, May 12, 2005 4:57 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid question


LOL, sorry mate, I wasn't asking if I COULD DO IT, but rather, are there
any professionals in Japan doing this sort of thing.

We would not expect you to be able to restore tsuba LOL.

Rich

> drip under pressure!!!), but when Trickie writes:
>
> > My question for the day then is, if we polish and restore pittings,
> > scratches, chips and the likes from swords, is anything like this
> > ever done on iron tsuba ?
>
> my answer would be
>
> NOooooooo...
>
> How do I know?? In my early days I stuffed a reasonable tsuba or two
> trying to "restore" them (boo, hisss, shame, brickbats...). So, I
> wouldn't advise this at all. Over to an expert???
>
> Regards,
>
> Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid question
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard; There was a tsubako at the San Fran show a couple of years ago from Japan.  He makes great sukashi tsuba.  Price in the 5K to 8K range.  He had a
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard;

There was a tsubako at the San Fran show a couple of years ago from Japan. He makes great sukashi tsuba. Price in the 5K to 8K range. He had a number of his tsuba on display, very nice work.

There are people in the US and in Japan that can do restoration on iron tsuba, and I have had some restored in both the US and in Japan.

I am not certain on kinko as I have never had one done.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, May 11, 2005 11:52 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid question


but I have been know to ask plenty of these in my life so why stand on
ceremony now :-).

I was looking at some pitting that is on a new tsuba I picked
( either Akasaka or Tosa Myochin I think -
http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba/akasaka2.jpg )
and it has a bit more pitting than I thought from the auction images
which is a shame.

My question for the day then is, if we polish and restore pittings,
scratches, chips and the likes from swords, is anything like this ever
done on iron tsuba ?, I know the obvious thing is the patina but if we
can re patinate nakago, why not tsuba ( at least iron tsuba anyway ) and
are there any artisans in Japan presently making tsuba in the old ways
and using original patina recipes ?. I know Yoshindo Yoshihara sensei
does apparently, and I would love to see some examples of his work. I
was thinking about this recently, and wondered about the recipes in the
back of the Aesthetic Guide and if anyone still does this stuff. If so,
could very good tsuba with minimal damage be repaired and re patinate
and if so, how effectively.

Right then, foot back in my mouth and over to the experts.

cheers

Rich Turner


--

Richard Turner
Nihontô Message Board
<http://members5.boardhost.com/Nihon-To/>
- /for the discussion and sharing of all things Nihontô/

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid question
messages.msgSnippet: ... my answer would be NOooooooo... How do I know??  In my early days I stuffed a reasonable tsuba or two trying to restore them  (boo, hisss, shame,
messages.messageBody:
I'm no expert by any means ("X" = an unknown factor and "spurt" is a drip under pressure!!!), but when Trickie writes:

> My question for the day then is, if we polish and restore pittings,
> scratches, chips and the likes from swords, is anything like this
> ever done on iron tsuba ?

my answer would be

NOooooooo...

How do I know?? In my early days I stuffed a reasonable tsuba or two trying to "restore" them (boo, hisss, shame, brickbats...). So, I wouldn't advise this at all. Over to an expert???

Regards,

Barry Thomas.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid question
messages.msgSnippet: I made this tsubas ( http://tinyurl.com/4ptgy ) has many mistakes (I m still learning with Gugliotta) but I want to know what do you think about the patina
messages.messageBody:
I made this tsubas ( http://tinyurl.com/4ptgy ) has many mistakes (I'm still
learning with Gugliotta) but I want to know what do you think about the
patina both are in steel SAE 1030 ( Iron + 0.30 carbon), with cooper, brass
and silver, I don´t know if they are too black or they must to look more
brown,
Thanks in advance
Máximo
PS. why don't you make a new one, and keep that in original condition.?
